Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Partial and Multilevel Effect Sizes in Meta-analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The investigators propose to develop and study partial effect-size indices for results of single and multilevel regression analyses and examine the suitability of the indices for use in meta-analysis. The investigators propose a program of work which combines mathematical statistics and simulation studies, illustrated with real educational examples. This work will provide guidelines that researchers can use in reporting results and effect sizes for complex primary-study analyses; facilitate meta-analyses of complex studies; and inform the conduct and reporting of primary studies in STEM research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most quantitative primary studies conducted today use some form of multivariate analysis to represent their results. Because scientific evidence benefits from the accumulative knowledge of the studies conducted in a specific field, we must have up-to-date methods to synthesize complex primary study results. In addition, one complexity that arises with the use of sophisticated multivariate models is that most studies in STEM education use arbitrary metrics to represent the outcome measures (e.g., science or mathematics academic achievement, motivation, self-efficacy, and many other latent constructs).  Consequently, most study results must be transformed onto a common metric so that they can be compared, contrasted, and summarized. That is, to cumulate complex studies, the effect size is of paramount importance. Thus, researchers need appropriate effect sizes to compare results of primary studies that used different measures of the same construct.

Our work made use of statistical theory to develop and/or study effect sizes and their respective variances computed from regression models. Because most complex primary studies use a form of regression analysis, one goal of our work was to learn about the individual behavior of effect sizes from regression models and their variances. Another goal was to study the consequences of synthesizing effect sizes from complex studies. 

Our findings indicate that when researchers are interested in relationships between two variables, adjusted by a set of covariates, most available effect sizes behave similarly with respect of their bias. These effect sizes are of the correlation family and includes the regression slope, partial correlation, and semi-partial correlation.  However, careful attention must be given to effect sizes that intend to capture the conditional relationship between a numerical and a categorical variable. These effect sizes fall into the standardized mean difference family, and are common when comparing group mean differences adjusted for the effect of confounders.

When using effect sizes from the correlation family, meta-analysts should carefully code other key variables are included in (or excluded from) the primary-study models from which effects are drawn. As the predictive power of the model increases, the more relevant those model differences are in the magnitude of the effect sizes. However, the intercorrelations between covariates also plays a critical role in effect-size magnitude regardless of the model fit. A second major concern with the standardized-mean-difference effect sizes is in the standardization metric.. Consequently, a synthesis of effect sizes that are not comparable may produce results that are not informative for policy or practice.

The work of this grant should aid researchers in deciding what effect size to use depending upon their research question(s). We also provide guidance about what effect sizes can be combined in meta-analyses. Consequently, this work not only provides tools for meta-analysis, but also has the potential to influence the way that research is being conducted and reported.
